First, I've built a network of connections – classmates, friends, and even some professors who are willing to look the other way or offer a bit of extra help when I need it. It's all about who you know, right? These connections can provide me with valuable insights into what's going to be on exams, what topics to focus on for assignments, and even give me access to past exams or assignments that I can, shall we say, "use for reference."

I'm also very strategic about how I use online resources. There are tons of websites and forums where you can find essays, term papers, and even entire courses' worth of material. The key is to not just copy and paste, but to use these resources as a starting point and then tailor the work to fit your own voice and style. And of course, I always make sure to cover my tracks, whether it's by using VPNs, deleting my browser history, or just being careful about who I talk to about my methods.

Another strategy I've found effective is to play the game of academic politics. Building a good relationship with your professors can go a long way. They're more likely to give you the benefit of the doubt, offer extensions on assignments, or even adjust your grades if you've built a rapport with them. It's not about being their favorite or anything, but about being someone they see as a dedicated, hardworking student – even if that's not entirely true.

Lastly, I've learned to be very adept at managing my time and prioritizing my efforts. I focus on the assignments and exams that are going to have the biggest impact on my grades and worry less about the smaller stuff. And if I need to, I'm not above "reappropriating" work from others or finding other ways to get the grades I need without putting in the actual work.

It's a delicate balance, but one that I've mastered over the years. And let's be real, in today's competitive academic environment, if you're not willing to bend the rules a bit, you're going to get left behind. I'm just doing what it takes to succeed.
